title: Cat. 41  Hôtel Colbert, Windows, 1891
publication_title: The Lithographs of James McNeill Whistler: The Digital Edition
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section body" id="body"> 411891Way: 35  
Levy: 60  
Transfer lithograph, drawn on medium-grained transfer paper  
Ink color: black  
Signature: printed butterfly, lower center on tablecloth  
One state; image size: 169 × 128 mm  
Number of impressions listed by Way: 8  
Printer: Way  
Watermarks: 41, 42, 113, 139, 141, 186, 190, 191, 271–73, 280, 309  
Posthumous edition: 21 impressions printed by Goulding on 2 November 1903  
Posthumous watermarks: 15, 165, 219, 220, 279, 298, 299  
Stone: erased in 1903  
Whistler-Way Letters: 34, 35, 84, 86; apps. I.1, II.3, II.4, III.2, V.1  
Selected Literature: Way, Studio (1896), p. 223  
Lifetime Exhibitions: London 1895–96 (no. 40, as Windows—Hôtel Colbert, Paris); New York 1898 (no. 310); London 1898–99 ? (no. 2002, as Hôtel Colbert, Paris); Chicago 1900b (no. 34)

Hôtel Colbert, Windows was drawn in Paris in the neighborhood of the Bibliothèque Nationale (see also cat. 42 and cat. 43). Whistler made at least two brief trips to Paris in 1891, the first from June 11 to 15 and the second in late October and early November. Both times he stayed at the Hôtel du Helder, on the boulevard des Capucines, within easy walking distance of the rue Colbert. The June trip was crowded with visits to exhibitions, friends, and fellow artists, while during the autumn sojourn Whistler spent much of his time working on lithographs with the printer Belfond. There is no specific evidence to suggest which of these Paris visits produced the Hotel Colbert lithographs, although the second trip seems the more likely.

T. R. Way’s (1905) citation of eight lifetime impressions is far too low. When Whistler died there were at least twenty-four impressions in his estate.

Chicago: AIC, ivory laid paper (322 × 205 mm), signed; MWC, tan laid paper (305 × 239 mm), signed; SC, ivory laid paper (311 × 203 mm). Glasgow: HAG (16), ivory laid paper (303 × 205 mm), signed; grayish ivory chine (207 × 142 mm) mounted on ivory plate paper (382 × 280 mm); grayish ivory chine (208 × 142 mm) mounted on ivory plate paper (383 × 280 mm); ivory laid paper (311 × 203 mm); ivory laid paper (308 × 202 mm); cream wove paper (317 × 201 mm); cream Japanese paper (319 × 202 mm); tan Japanese paper (310 × 207 mm); cream Japanese paper (277 × 201 mm); ivory Japanese paper (318 × 201 mm); ivory Japanese paper (318 × 201 mm); cream wove paper (316 × 198 mm); cream Japanese paper (278 × 203 mm); grayish ivory chine (208 × 142 mm) mounted on ivory plate paper (383 × 280 mm); tan laid paper (282 × 239 mm); cream wove paper (317 × 200 mm). London: BM, cream laid paper (281 × 225 mm). Washington: FGA, cream laid paper (317 × 204 mm); NGA, cream laid paper (323 × 206 mm), signed.

Remarks: Other impressions are found in Brooklyn, TBM; and New York, MMA (2).  
Nesta R. Spink, Harriet K. Stratis, Martha Tedeschi

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">Belfond’s premises on the rue Gaillon were also near the Bibliothèque Nationale.

The number is either twenty-four or twenty-seven, depending on how one interprets the notations in Rosalind Birnie Philip’s inventory, where four signed, twenty unsigned, and three mounted impressions are listed; GUL LB6; transcribed in MacDonald (1988), p. 40.
